required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Reducing Maternal Stress to Improve Obesity-related Parenting Practices
clinical_study.official_title: Reducing Maternal Stress to Improve Obesity-related Parenting Practices

collaborator.agency: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH)

brief_summary.textblock: Maternal stress is associated with children's risk for obesity controlling for socioeconomic status. The association between maternal stress and child obesity is particularly strong in Latinx families, whose children also have the highest rates of obesity in the United States. A mindful parenting program might reduce Latina mothers' psychological stress and lead to improved parenting practices and ability to create a healthier environment. The primary objective of the proposed research is to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a culturally-relevant intervention that integrates mindfulness-based stress reduction and mindful parenting in Latina mothers. The investigators will conduct a randomized clinical trial comparing the ATIENDE (Awareness Training to Influence Eating, Nutrition, Decision-making, and Exercise) intervention to an active control condition in 50 Latina mothers of elementary-school age children. Participant satisfaction rates and qualitative interviews will provide evidence of the program's acceptability. Feasibility will be determined by examining recruitment rates, retention rates, and treatment fidelity. Completion of this project will inform the development of a full-scale efficacy trial.

primary_outcome.measure: Participant Satisfaction with Intervention Assessed by the Client Satisfaction Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: Parents will be asked to complete a brief, 8-item, widely used measure of satisfaction with health-related services, available in Spanish and English. Scores range from 8 to 32, with higher values indicating higher satisfaction.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At the beginning of each of the 6 weekly intervention sessions
primary_outcome.description: Research staff will take attendance during each intervention session.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (Spanish version) is a 39-item self-report measure of five facets of mindfulness: observing, describing, acting with awareness, non-judgment, and non-reactivity. Scores range from 39 to 190 with higher scores suggesting greater mindfulness.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the Perceived Stress Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The Perceived Stress Scale is a 10-item, widely used self-report measure of perceptions of psychological stress. Scores range from 0 to 40 with higher scores indicating greater perceived stress.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the Child Feeding Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The Child Feeding Questionnaire is a 31-item self-report questionnaire that assesses parents' beliefs, attitudes, and approaches toward feeding their children. Scores range from 31 to 155 with higher scores representing greater use of controlling feeding practices.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the Frequency of Family Eating and Exercise Behaviors Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: 28 items used in previous work by Neumark-Sztainer et al. will be used to assess eating and weight-related habits of families. Items assess: frequency of family meals, fast food consumption, and watching TV during meals; availability of fruits and vegetables and sugar sweetened beverages; and parents' encouragement of healthy food consumption and physical activity.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Height will be measured to the nearest 0.1cm using a precision stadiometer.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Weight will be measured to the nearest 0.1kg using a digital scale.

other_outcome.measure: Change in Child Daily Kilocalories via 3-Day Food Record
other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: Participants will be trained to complete a 3-day food record (using a detailed food record form) to track dietary intake for 2 weekdays and 1 weekend day in the week prior to their assessment. Diet will be analyzed via Nutrition Data System Software (NDSR). Average kilocalories per day will be the primary dietary outcome.

other_outcome.measure: Change in Child Frequency of Physical Activity as Assessed by the Physical Activity Recall Screen
other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: Children's frequency of physical activity will be assessed using the Physical Activity Recall. This interview measure asks respondents to report the amount of time they spent in moderate and vigorous activities during the previous 7 days.

other_outcome.measure: Change in Child Quality of Life as Assessed by the Pediatric Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire
other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: The Pediatric Quality of Life Questionnaire is a 23-item measure of perceptions of how health affects daily life in 4 areas: physical, emotional, social, and school. Scores range from 0 - 100, with higher scores indicating greater quality of life.

other_outcome.measure: Change in Child Weight in Kilograms
other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: Weight will be measured to the nearest 0.1kg using a digital scale.

other_outcome.measure: Change in Child Height in Meters
other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: Height will be measured to the nearest 0.1cm using a precision stadiometer.

other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will complete this at three timepoints: baseline, immediately after the intervention, and 10-months from baseline
other_outcome.description: Accelerometers (Actigraph GT3X) will be worn for 1 week by children for each assessment period to assess physical activity objectively.

arm_group.description: Attention-matched comparator group designed to influence health and well-being that does not include mindfulness as an active ingredient

intervention.description: A mix of mindfulness-based stress reduction, mindful eating, and mindful parenting strategies.
Consists of strategies meant to enhance health and well-being (e.g., music therapy, health education) but does not include mindfulness as an active ingredient.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- over the age of 18 years
- identify as female
- identify as Hispanic or Latina
- have a child between the ages of 6 and 11 years who primarily resides with them
- either mother is considered to have overweight or obesity (BMI>25kg/m2) and/or their child is considered to have overweight or obesity (BMI for age and sex >85th percentile)
- able to understand basic instructions in either Spanish or English
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant or planning on becoming pregnant in the near future
- actively dependent on a substance
- have untreated psychosis, PTSD, or social anxiety that would impair their ability to function in a group setting
- child has an obesity-associated genetic syndrome
- child has a pervasive developmental disorder
